title: 105_hr1621
content: The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 may be cited as the "Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997" and it specifies the duration of copyright provisions. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997, also known as the "Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997," amends Section 301(c) of title 17, United States Code, changing the date to February 15, 2067. It also amends Section 302 of title 17, United States Code, increasing the duration of copyright for works created on or after January 1, 1978. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 further amends copyright duration laws by increasing the copyright term to 120 years for works created on or after January 1, 1978. Additionally, the Act extends the duration of copyright for works created but not published or copyrighted before January 1, 1978, to December 31, 2047. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 increases the copyright term to 120 years for works created after January 1, 1978. It also extends the duration of copyright for works created before January 1, 1978, to December 31, 2047. Amendments include changing "47" to "67" in various subparagraphs and subsections. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 extends the copyright term to 120 years for works created after January 1, 1978. Any copyright still in its renewal term at the time of the Act shall have a term of 95 years from the date it was originally secured. Termination rights provided in subsection (c) that have expired before the Act's effective date are addressed. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 extends the copyright term to 120 years for works created after January 1, 1978. Termination rights for copyrights in their renewal term at the time of the Act that have expired before the Act's effective date are subject to termination under specific conditions. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 extends copyright term to 120 years for works created after January 1, 1978. Termination of the grant can be done within 5 years at the end of 75 years from the original copyright date. Amendments were made to the Copyright Renewal Act of 1992, changing the renewal term to 67 years. REPRODUCTION BY LIBRARIES AND ARCHIVES. Section 108 of title 17, United States Code, allows libraries and archives to reproduce, distribute, display, or perform copyrighted works for preservation, scholarship, or research purposes during the last 20 years of the copyright term. This provision does not apply if the work is still commercially exploited. The exemption under Section 108 of title 17, United States Code, allows libraries and archives to reproduce, distribute, display, or perform copyrighted works if the work is subject to normal commercial exploitation, can be obtained at a reasonable price, or if the copyright owner provides notice. This exemption does not apply to subsequent uses by users other than the library or archives. SEC. 4. DISTRIBUTION OF PHONORECORDS. Amends Section 303 of title 17, United States Code regarding the distribution of phonorecords. Specifies that distribution before January 1, 1978, does not constitute publication of the musical work for copyright purposes. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATES. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the enactment date, except for cases involving distribution of phonorecords where previous legal actions were dismissed before the enactment date.
